answers.answer: since you had a transfusion before they began testing the blood supply for it, you probably got the exposure there. However if they found antibodies, they should have run further RNA test to make sure antibodies were ALL you had.Hep A and B can clear on their own, and Hep c as well but rarely.you need to find out what type and subtype you have and have the best Viral Load tests accurate to 10 viral cells per millileter of blood to say definitely you are free of these virus.even if you get the "all clear" on these, I'd still advise retesting every 3 years just to make sure you didn't get an inaccurate test or have an emerge from non-detectable to full blown, which can happen.yes you should tell your doctor you had a transfusion. the mono weakens the spleen, and can make liver virus harder to fight, but the main thing is to say you had transfusions because otherwise they may assume you have no point of exposure and hence not fully test.Not to try to scare you, but if you had any IV drug use before 77 you need to tell the doc that too as your children can be exposed through the birthing and nursing processes, my son was. He also cleared the virus on his own, which is rare, but thank God.My take, is it's better to really know exactly whats going on with you and your family, not to wait and wonder. Learn what questions to ask and what tests to get. See a hepatologist if you possibly can.hope that helps.

question: I had mono in 1974.  I had my first baby in 1977 and had to receive a blood transfusion after a vaginal delivery.  In the late 1980's when I gave blood at my work, the blood bank gave me a card that said I had an anti-duffy antibody in my blood.  Since I developed diabetes in 1994 I have never given blood again.  I have two questions.  What does it mean to have this antibody in my blood and also should I ever tell my doctor that I had mono and a blood transfusion?  I have no symptons of hepatitis but I'm curious more than anything to know if I should be aware of anything in the future?Thank you.
title: Hepatitis aftr mono and blood trans
